data.source: 2006 Federal Human Capital Survey (FHCS) administered by the U.S. Office of Personnel Management
data.notes: Dataset is representative of full-time, permanent employees on key demographic and geographic indicators.

method.description: The authors constructed two dichotomous turnover-intention variables from the 2006 FHCS (leaving one’s agency for another federal job; leaving the federal government for an external job) and modeled these using logistic regression with robust standard errors clustered by agency. They included three clusters of predictors—demographic, workplace-satisfaction, and organizational/relational factors—and ran Monte-Carlo simulations (Clarify in Stata 11) to compute predicted probabilities and first differences.
steps: Derive two dependent variables from the question on whether the respondent is considering leaving within the next year (Leaving Agency, Leaving Government).

Generate independent variables: demographic dummies (age categories, tenure, race), workplace satisfaction measures (overall job satisfaction, pay, benefits, advancement), organizational/relational measures (performance culture factor score, empowerment, supervisor and coworker relationship scores) plus interaction terms.
Estimate two logistic regression models with robust standard errors clustered by agency—one for each turnover measure.
Use Monte Carlo simulations via Clarify (Stata 11) to compute predicted probabilities and first-difference effects.
Interpret coefficients and simulated effects to identify substantive predictors of turnover intention.
method.models: Logistic regression (with robust SEs clustered by agency) and Monte-Carlo simulation of predicted probabilities
method.outcome_variable: Turnover intention (1 = intends to leave; 0 = otherwise), measured separately for Leaving Agency and Leaving Government
method.independent_variables: Age categories; agency tenure; race/ethnicity; overall job satisfaction; satisfaction with pay; satisfaction with benefits; satisfaction with advancement; performance culture factor; empowerment; relationship with supervisor; relationship with coworkers; age × advancement and age × benefits interactions
method.control_variables: Same set of demographic, satisfaction, and organizational variables included jointly in the models

results.summary: Overall job satisfaction, age, and satisfaction with advancement opportunities are the strongest predictors of turnover intention. Higher job satisfaction and satisfaction with advancement reduce the likelihood of both forms of turnover, while middle-aged employees are more likely than the youngest group to consider moving within the federal service but less likely to exit the federal government. A stronger performance culture slightly increases intentions to leave one’s agency. Positive supervisor relationships decrease intentions to leave the agency, whereas empowerment and coworker relations show limited influence.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Predicted probability of intending to leave agency at mean covariates

metadata.original_paper_title: So Hard to Say Goodbye? Turnover Intention among U.S. Federal Employees
